The application for registration and special ballot shall be in the prescribed form and shall include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the elector’s name and the address of his or her place of ordinary residence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the elector’s date of birth;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: satisfactory proof of the elector’s identity and residence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the elector’s mailing address; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other information that the Chief Electoral Officer considers necessary to determine the elector’s entitlement to vote or the electoral district in which he or she may vote.

Subsection.Text: An elector who would be under reasonable apprehension of bodily harm if he or she were to indicate the address of his or her place of ordinary residence or his or her mailing address for the purpose of paragraph (1)(a) or (d) may apply to the returning officer or special voting rules administrator to use another address for that purpose. The returning officer or special voting rules administrator, unless he or she considers that it would not be in the public interest to do so, shall grant the application and shall not reveal the addresses in respect of which the application is made except as required to send the special ballot to the elector. For greater certainty, the granting of the application does not change the elector’s place of ordinary residence for the purposes of this Act.

In addition to the information specified in subsection (1), the Chief Electoral Officer may request that the elector provide other information that the Chief Electoral Officer considers necessary to implement agreements made under section 55, but the elector is not required to provide that information.

Section.Text: Once an elector’s application for registration and special ballot has been accepted, the elector may only vote under this Division.

Once an elector’s application for registration and special ballot has been accepted by the returning officer or special voting rules administrator, he or she shall ensure, in accordance with the Chief Election Officer’s instructions,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the elector’s name is entered on the list of electors for the polling division of the elector’s place of ordinary residence, if it is not already included on a list of electors; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that there is an indication on the list of electors that the elector has received a special ballot.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2) and section 237.1, on acceptance of an elector’s application for registration and special ballot, the elector shall be provided with a special ballot.
If section 241 applies, then, on acceptance of an elector’s application for registration and special ballot, the elector shall be given a ballot, an inner envelope and an outer envelope.

If an elector goes to the office of a returning officer to receive his or her ballot or special ballot, then before receiving it the elector shall prove his or her identity and residence in accordance with section 143.
A candidate or their representative may be present at the office when the elector

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: receives the ballot;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: places the folded ballot in the inner envelope and seals it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: places the inner envelope in the outer envelope and seals it.

Subsection.Text: The candidate or representative may examine but not handle any piece of identification provided by the elector.

For the purposes of this section, the following provisions apply with any necessary modifications in respect of the location in the returning officer’s office where the elector receives his or her ballot or special ballot as though that location were a polling station:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sections 135 to 137;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sections 143 to 144;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 164(1);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: section 166;

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: subsections 281.6(1) to (4);

Paragraph.Label: (d.2)
Paragraph.Text: section 282.2; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 489(3)(c).

Section.Text: An elector who has been provided with a special ballot may vote only by following the procedure set out in subsections 227(2) and (3).

Section.MarginalNote: Receipt of special ballot — application made outside electoral district

Subsection.Text: In order to have their special ballot counted, an elector whose application for registration and special ballot was accepted by the special voting rules administrator or by a returning officer outside the elector’s electoral district shall ensure that the special ballot is received by the special voting rules administrator in the National Capital Region no later than 6:00 p.m. on polling day. The special ballot shall be transmitted by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sending the sealed outer envelope to the special voting rules administrator by mail or any other means; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: delivering it to a Canadian Embassy, High Commission or Consular Office, to a Canadian Forces base outside Canada or to any other place that the Chief Electoral Officer designates.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Receipt of special ballot — application made in electoral district
Subsection.Text: In order to have their special ballot counted, an elector whose application for registration and special ballot was accepted by the returning officer in the elector’s electoral district shall ensure that the ballot is received at the office of that returning officer before the close of the polling stations on polling day.

Despite subsection (2), a special ballot referred to in that subsection that is received by the special voting rules administrator in the National Capital Region no later than 6:00 p.m. on polling day shall be counted.

Section.Text: For the purpose of this Division, an elector has the sole responsibility to ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: his or her application for registration and special ballot is made within the period specified; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: his or her special ballot is received within the period specified to be counted as a vote.

Section.MarginalNote: Elector to be given regular ballot
Section.Text: An elector who applies to vote in person at the office of the returning officer for his or her electoral district after ballots for the electoral district have been printed shall be given a ballot that is not a special ballot and shall immediately vote in the manner described in paragraphs 151(1)(a) and (b) and 227(2)(b) to (d) and return the outer envelope to the election officer.

If, under section 241, an elector is given a ballot that is not a special ballot, no marking shall be placed on the back of the ballot in the space otherwise indicated in Form 3 of Schedule 1 for a polling division number.

Subsection.Text: If the ballot or special ballot is incapable of being used, the elector shall return it to the election officer, who shall mark it as a spoiled ballot and give the elector another ballot or special ballot.
An elector shall not be given more than one ballot or special ballot, as the case may be, under subsection (1).

When an elector personally goes to the office of the returning officer and is unable to read or because of a disability is unable to vote in the manner described in this Division, the designated election officer shall assist the elector by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: completing the declaration referred to in paragraph 227(2)(c) and writing the elector’s name where the elector’s signature is to be written; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: marking the ballot as directed by the elector in the elector’s presence.

Subsection.Text: An election officer who assists an elector under subsection (1) shall indicate, by signing the note on the declaration, that the elector was assisted.

Section.MarginalNote: Assistance by friend or related person

Subsection.Text: If an elector requires assistance to vote, one of the following persons may accompany the elector into the voting compartment at the office of the returning officer and assist the elector to mark his or her ballot:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a friend of the elector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the elector’s spouse or common-law partner; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a relative of the elector or of the elector’s spouse or common-law partner.

Subsection.Text: A person described in subsection (1) who wishes to assist an elector in marking a ballot shall first make a solemn declaration in the prescribed form that he or she

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: will mark the ballot paper in the manner directed by the elector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: will not disclose the name of the candidate for whom the elector voted;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: will not try to influence the elector in choosing a candidate; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: has not, during the current election, assisted another person, as a friend, to mark a ballot.

Subsection.Text: On application of an elector who is unable to read — or who is unable to vote in the manner described in this Division because of a disability — and who is unable to personally go to the office of the returning officer because of a disability, an election officer shall go to the elector’s dwelling place and, in the presence of a witness who is chosen by the elector, assist the elector by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: completing the declaration referred to in paragraph 227(2)(c) and writing the elector’s name where the elector’s signature is to be written; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: marking the ballot as directed by the elector in the elector’s presence.

Subsection.Text: The election officer and the witness who assist an elector under subsection (1) shall indicate, by signing the note on the declaration, that the elector was assisted.

Section.Text: For the purpose of this Division, elector means an incarcerated elector.
This Division does not apply to an elector who is incarcerated in a place designated under subsection 205(1) of the National Defence Act.

Subsection.Text: Every elector is entitled to vote under this Division on the 12th day before polling day.
An elector is not entitled to vote under this Division unless he or she has signed an application for registration and special ballot under section 251 and a declaration described in section 257.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Vote to be in electoral district
Subsection.Text: An elector is entitled to vote under this Division only for a candidate in the electoral district in which his or her place of ordinary residence is situated as shown on the application for registration and special ballot made by the elector under section 251.

Section.Text: The federal and provincial ministers responsible for correctional institutions shall each designate a person as a coordinating officer to work, during and between elections, with the Chief Electoral Officer to carry out the purposes and provisions of this Division.

Section.MarginalNote: Notification of issue of the writs

Subsection.Text: Without delay after the issue of the writs, the Chief Electoral Officer shall inform the federal and provincial ministers responsible for correctional institutions of their issue.
On being informed of the issue of the writs, each minister referred to in subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inform their respective designated coordinating officer of their issue;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: designate one or more persons to act as liaison officers in connection with the taking of the votes of electors; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: inform the Chief Electoral Officer and their respective designated coordinating officer of the name and address of each liaison officer.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall appoint persons designated under paragraph 247(2)(b) in the prescribed form.

During the election period, a liaison officer shall cooperate with the Chief Electoral Officer in the administration of the registration and the taking of the votes of electors, including by informing the Chief Electoral Officer of the identity of the electors who received a special ballot.

Section.Text: When a coordinating officer is informed that a liaison officer has been designated, the coordinating officer shall give the liaison officer all necessary information on taking the votes of electors.

Subsection.Text: A liaison officer shall, without delay after being appointed, post a notice in the prescribed form in a prominent place in the correctional institution that informs electors of the date on which they are entitled to vote in accordance with this Division.

The polling stations shall be open on the 12th day before polling day from 9:00 a.m. and shall be kept open until every elector who is registered under subsection 251(1) has voted, but in no case shall they be kept open later than 8:00 p.m. on that day.

Section.MarginalNote: Application for registration and special ballot

Subsection.Text: Before the 12th day before polling day, each liaison officer shall ensure that an application for registration and special ballot in the prescribed form is completed for every eligible elector of the correctional institution who wishes to vote, indicating his or her place of ordinary residence as determined under subsection (2).
The place of ordinary residence of an elector is the first of the following places for which the elector knows the civic and mailing addresses:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: his or her residence before being incarcerated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the residence of the spouse, the common-law partner, a relative or a dependant of the elector, a relative of his or her spouse or common-law partner or a person with whom the elector would live but for his or her incarceration;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the place of his or her arrest; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the last court where the elector was convicted and sentenced.

Subsection.Text: In addition to providing his or her place of ordinary residence, the Chief Electoral Officer may request that the elector provide other information that the Chief Electoral Officer considers necessary to implement agreements made under section 55, but the elector is not required to provide that information.

The liaison officer shall validate the application for registration and special ballot by signing it and indicating on it the name of the electoral district that includes the place of ordinary residence as determined under subsection (2).

If a dispute arises as to in which electoral district an elector may vote, the elector may refer the matter to the returning officer for the electoral district where the correctional institution is located, and the returning officer shall make a final determination in accordance with the process for revising lists of electors.

Section.Text: Applications for registration and special ballot are deemed to be the list of electors who vote under this Division.

Subsection.Text: Before the 18th day before polling day, each returning officer shall, for each correctional institution in his or her electoral district, in consultation with the liaison officer for the institution, establish one or more polling stations and assign at least two election officers to each polling station.
A liaison officer shall, on receiving the election materials and list of candidates,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide, as necessary, the materials to the election officers who are assigned under subsection (1) to a polling station for the correctional institution; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: post the list of candidates in one or more conspicuous places in the correctional institution.

Section.Text: On the day on which the electors cast their ballots, at each polling station an election officer who is assigned to the polling station shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post two or more copies of the voting instructions, in the prescribed form, in conspicuous places; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep readily available for consultation by electors a copy of this Part, a set of street indexes, a guide to electoral districts and a list of candidates.

Subsection.Text: A liaison officer shall, when required, establish a mobile polling station within a correctional institution to take the votes of the electors who are confined to their cells or in an infirmary.

A returning officer may, in cooperation with liaison officers, create a mobile polling station for correctional institutions of fewer than 50 electors that are within the returning officer’s electoral district and that are within reasonable travelling distance of each other.

Section.Text: With the prior authorization of correctional authorities, a Canadian citizen may represent a registered party during the taking of the votes at a correctional institution if he or she provides an election officer who is assigned to a polling station at the correctional institution with an authorization in the prescribed form signed by a candidate for that party, or a copy of one.

Subsection.Text: Before delivering a special ballot to an elector, an election officer who is assigned to a polling station at a correctional institution shall require the elector to complete an application for registration and special ballot, if the elector has not already done so, and to sign the declaration on the outer envelope.
After the elector has signed the declaration on the outer envelope, the election officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sign the outer envelope; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give the elector a special ballot, an inner envelope and the outer envelope.

Subsection.Text: The elector shall vote by writing on the special ballot the name of the candidate of his or her choice, folding it and, in the presence of the election officer,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: placing the ballot in the inner envelope and sealing the envelope; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: placing the inner envelope in the outer envelope and sealing the outer envelope.

Subsection.Text: The candidate shall be indicated on a special ballot by writing the candidate’s given name or initials and surname. If two or more candidates have the same name, their political affiliations shall be indicated.
If the special ballot is incapable of being used, the elector shall return it to the election officer, who shall mark it as a spoiled ballot and give the elector another special ballot.
An elector shall not be given more than one special ballot under subsection (3).

If an elector is unable to read or because of a disability is unable to vote in the manner described in this Division, an election officer who is assigned to the polling station shall assist the elector by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: completing the declaration on the outer envelope and writing the elector’s name where his or her signature is to be written; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: marking the special ballot as directed by the elector in his or her presence and in the presence of another election officer who is assigned to the polling station.

Subsection.Text: The election officers shall sign a note on the outer envelope indicating that the elector was assisted.

Section.MarginalNote: Delivery of documents after the vote
Section.Text: Without delay after the votes have been cast at a correctional institution, an election officer who is assigned to the polling station shall deliver to the liaison officer for the institution

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the outer envelopes that contain the marked special ballots;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any unused or spoiled outer envelopes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any unused or spoiled special ballots and unused inner envelopes; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the applications for registration and special ballot.

Section.MarginalNote: Deadline for return of election material
Section.Text: Every liaison officer shall ensure that the election material referred to in section 260 is received by the special voting rules administrator in the National Capital Region no later than 6:00 p.m. on polling day.

Section.MarginalNote: Integration into final list of electors
Section.Text: The applications for registration and special ballot shall be integrated into the final list of electors referred to in section 109.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 6
Heading.TitleText: Counting of Votes at the Office of the Chief Electoral Officer

Section.Text: This Division applies to the counting of all special ballots cast in accordance with this Part, except those referred to in Division 7.

Subsection.Text: The counting of the special ballots shall be conducted by special ballot officers under the supervision of the special voting rules administrator.
Special ballot officers shall work in pairs of persons representing different registered parties.

Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall prescribe security instructions for the safekeeping of special ballots, inner envelopes, outer envelopes and all other election documents, and instructions for the receiving, sorting and counting of special ballots.
The counting of votes shall commence on a date to be fixed by the Chief Electoral Officer or, if no date is fixed, on Wednesday, the 5th day before polling day.

Subsection.Text: The special ballot officers shall set aside an inner envelope unopened if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information concerning the elector, as set out in the declaration referred to in paragraph 227(2)(c) or subsection 257(1), does not correspond with the information on the application for registration and special ballot;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a declaration referred to in paragraph (a) or in section 212 — other than one in respect of an elector who has voted with assistance under section 216, 243 or 259 — does not bear the elector’s signature;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the correct electoral district of the elector whose ballot is contained in the inner envelope cannot be ascertained;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the outer envelope has been received by the special voting rules administrator in the National Capital Region after 6:00 p.m. on polling day; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the outer envelope relates to an electoral district for which the election was postponed in accordance with section 77.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Procedure when elector votes more than once
Subsection.Text: If, after receiving an elector’s outer envelope but before counting the inner envelopes, the special ballot officers ascertain that the elector has voted more than once, they shall set the elector’s inner envelope aside unopened.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Disposition of inner envelopes that are set aside
Subsection.Text: When an inner envelope is set aside unopened as described in subsection (1) or (2),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it shall be endorsed by the special voting rules administrator with the reason why it has been set aside;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least two special ballot officers shall initial the endorsement; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an inner envelope set aside under subsection (1), the ballot contained in it is deemed to be a spoiled ballot.

Subsection.Text: When an inner envelope is set aside unopened as described in this section, it shall be kept with the outer envelope and — if it did not appear on the outer envelope — the declaration.
If a dispute arises regarding the setting aside of inner envelopes, it shall be referred to the special voting rules administrator, whose decision is final.
The special voting rules administrator shall prepare a report in respect of the number of inner envelopes that are set aside under this Division.

Section.Text: Each pair of special ballot officers shall count the votes for only one electoral district or part of an electoral district at a time.

Subsection.Text: Each pair of special ballot officers shall, on examining a special ballot, reject it if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it has not been supplied by the Chief Electoral Officer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is not marked;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it is marked with a name other than the name of a candidate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: it is marked with the names of more than one candidate; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: there is any writing or mark on it by which the elector could be identified.

Subsection.Text: No special ballot shall be rejected for the sole reason that the elector has incorrectly written the name of a candidate, if the ballot clearly indicates the elector’s intent.
If a dispute arises as to the validity of a special ballot, it shall be referred to the special voting rules administrator, whose decision is final.
The number of disputed special ballots and the name of the electoral district in which they were cast are to be noted by the special ballot officers.
Each pair of special ballot officers shall prepare a statement of the vote in the prescribed form and deliver it to the special voting rules administrator.
The special voting rules administrator shall keep the statements of the vote in safe custody until the day after the communication of the results under section 280.
On request, after the day that the results are communicated, a special ballot officer may be given a copy of the statement of the vote that he or she prepared.

Section.MarginalNote: Chief Electoral Officer to be informed of results of vote
Section.Text: Without delay after the counting of the votes for every electoral district has been completed, the special voting rules administrator shall inform the Chief Electoral Officer of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the number of votes counted for each candidate for every electoral district;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the total number of votes counted for each electoral district; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of rejected ballots for each electoral district.

Section.MarginalNote: Sending of material to Chief Electoral Officer
Section.Text: As soon as practicable after the counting of the votes for every electoral district has been completed, the special voting rules administrator shall send to the Chief Electoral Officer, in separate envelopes,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the lists of electors;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all other documents and election materials received from commanding officers and election officers;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the solemn declarations made under subsection 23(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the complete files of correspondence, reports and records in his or her possession.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 7
Heading.TitleText: Counting of Votes in the Office of the Returning Officer

Section.Text: The returning officer shall, as soon as possible, notify the candidates of the names of the election officers who he or she assigns to verify the declarations referred to in paragraph 227(2)(c) and to count the special ballots issued to electors in his or her electoral district and received at his or her office.

A candidate or his or her representative may be present for the verification of the declarations referred to in paragraph 227(2)(c) and the counting of ballots received at the returning officer’s office.

Subsection.Text: The returning officer shall ensure that the ballots received at his or her office are kept sealed until they are given to an election officer referred to in section 273.
All outer envelopes received after the prescribed deadline shall be kept separate and sealed and shall be initialled by the returning officer and marked with the date and time of their receipt.

The election officers referred to in section 273 shall verify the declarations made under paragraph 227(2)(c), at the time fixed by the Chief Electoral Officer and in accordance with his or her instructions, by determining from the information in the declaration whether the elector is entitled to vote in the electoral district.
The returning officer shall notify the candidates of the time and place of the verification.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Provision of materials to election officer
Subsection.Text: One of the election officers shall be provided with the applications for registration and special ballot received before the deadline, along with any other materials that may be required.
An election officer referred to in section 273 shall set aside an elector’s inner envelope unopened if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information concerning the elector, as set out in the elector’s declaration made under paragraph 227(2)(c), does not correspond with the information on the application for registration and special ballot;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the declaration — other than one in respect of an elector who has voted with assistance under section 243 or 243.1 — does not bear the elector’s signature;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the elector has voted more than once; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the outer envelope was received after the prescribed deadline.

Subsection.Text: When the declarations are verified, an election officer referred to in section 273 shall register any objection to an elector’s right to vote in the electoral district in the prescribed form.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Noting of reasons for setting aside
Subsection.Text: When an elector’s inner envelope is set aside unopened as described in subsection (1), the election officer who set it aside shall note on it the reasons for the setting aside. The election officer and another election officer referred to in section 273 shall both initial the envelope.
When an elector’s inner envelope is set aside unopened as described in this section, it shall be kept with the outer envelope and — if it did not appear on the outer envelope — the declaration.
The election officers referred to in section 273 shall count all inner envelopes that have not been set aside.
They shall put all the inner envelopes that have not been set aside in a ballot box provided by the returning officer.

After the close of the polling stations, one of the election officers shall open the ballot box and, together with another of the election officers, shall open the inner envelopes and count the votes.
An election officer shall, in counting the ballots, reject a ballot if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it has not been supplied for the election;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is not marked;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it is marked with a name other than the name of a candidate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: it is marked for more than one candidate; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: there is any writing or mark on it by which the elector could be identified.

Subsection.Text: An election officer shall not reject a special ballot for the sole reason that the elector has incorrectly written the name of a candidate, if the ballot clearly indicates the elector’s intent.

An election officer shall not reject a special ballot for the sole reason that the elector has written, in addition to the name of a candidate, the candidate’s political affiliation, if the ballot clearly indicates the elector’s intent.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 8
Heading.TitleText: Communication of the Results of the Vote

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall, without delay after the closing of the polling stations at an election, inform each returning officer of the results of the count under Division 6 for the returning officer’s electoral district, giving the number of votes cast for each candidate and the number of rejected ballots.

When the returning officer receives information from the Chief Electoral Officer respecting the results of the count under Division 6, the returning officer shall add those results to the results of the count under Division 7 and release all of them as being the results of the vote under the Special Voting Rules.

Section.Text: The provisions of this Part apply inside and outside Canada.
The Chief Electoral Officer shall not vote at an election.

Section.MarginalNote: Inducing Chief Electoral Officer to vote
Section.Text: No person shall induce or attempt to induce the Chief Electoral Officer to vote at an election knowing that it is the Chief Electoral Officer whom he or she is inducing or attempting to induce to vote and that the Chief Electoral Officer is prohibited from voting.
No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vote or attempt to vote at an election knowing that he or she

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is not a Canadian citizen when he or she votes, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is not 18 years of age or older — or will not be 18 years of age or older — on polling day; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: induce or attempt to induce another person to vote at an election knowing that the other person

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is not a Canadian citizen — or will not be a Canadian citizen — when he or she votes, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is not 18 years of age or older — or will not be 18 years of age or older — on polling day.

Section.MarginalNote: Not ordinarily resident in electoral district
Section.Text: No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vote or attempt to vote at an election in a particular electoral district knowing that his or her place of ordinary residence is not in that electoral district; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: induce or attempt to induce another person to vote at an election in a particular electoral district knowing that the other person’s place of ordinary residence is not in that electoral district.

Section.MarginalNote: Voting more than once — general election

Subsection.Text: No person who has voted in a general election shall vote again, or attempt to vote again, in that general election.
No person who has voted in a by-election shall vote again, or attempt to vote again, at that by-election or at any other by-election that is held on the same day.
Every person present at a polling station or at the counting of the votes shall maintain the secrecy of the vote.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Attempting to obtain information about elector’s vote
Subsection.Text: Except as provided by this Act, no person shall, in a polling station, attempt to obtain any information as to the candidate for whom any elector is about to vote or has voted.
Except as provided by this Act, no person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on entering the polling station and before receiving a ballot or special ballot, openly declare for whom he or she intends to vote;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while in the polling station, show his or her ballot or special ballot, when marked, so as to allow the name of the candidate for whom he or she has voted to be seen; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: before leaving the polling station, openly declare for whom he or she has voted.

Subsection.Text: No person who has seen a ballot or special ballot that has been marked by an elector shall disclose information as to how it was marked unless he or she is the elector who marked it or he or she has been authorized to make the disclosure by the elector who marked it.

No person shall, at the counting of the votes, attempt to obtain information or communicate information obtained at the counting as to the candidate for whom a vote is given in a particular ballot or special ballot.
No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: request or apply for a ballot or special ballot in a name that is not his or her own;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: vote using a forged ballot or forged special ballot;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: request or apply for a ballot or special ballot to which he or she is not entitled;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide a ballot or special ballot to any person when not authorized under this Act to do so;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: have a ballot or special ballot in his or her possession when not authorized under this Act to do so;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: alter, deface or destroy a ballot, the initials of the election officer that are signed on a ballot or the number of the polling division or advance polling district that is marked on a ballot;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: put or cause to be put into a ballot box a ballot, special ballot or other paper otherwise than as provided by this Act or by instructions of the Chief Electoral Officer;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: take a ballot out of the polling station or the office of the returning officer otherwise than as provided by this Act or by instructions of the Chief Electoral Officer; or

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: destroy, take, open or otherwise interfere with a ballot box or book or packet of ballots or special ballots otherwise than as provided by this Act or by instructions of the Chief Electoral Officer.

Subsection.Text: No election officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with the intent of causing the reception of a vote that should not have been cast or the non-reception of a vote that should have been cast, put his or her initials on the back of any paper purporting to be or capable of being used as a ballot at an election; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: place on a ballot or special ballot any writing, number or mark with intent that the elector to whom the ballot or special ballot is to be given, or has been given, can be identified.

Subsection.Text: No unit election officer shall place on a special ballot any writing, number or mark with intent that the elector to whom the special ballot is to be given, or has been given, can be identified.

Section.MarginalNote: Photograph, video or copy of marked ballot

Subsection.Text: No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: take a photograph or make a video recording of a ballot or special ballot that has been marked, at an election, by an elector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make a copy, in any manner, of any ballot or special ballot that has been marked, at an election, by an elector; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: distribute or show, in any manner, to one or more persons, a photograph, video recording or copy of a ballot or special ballot that has been marked, at an election, by an elector.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to any person with a visual impairment who takes a photograph or makes a video recording or copy of a ballot or special ballot that he or she has marked for the purpose of verifying the accuracy of their marking.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a person who does anything referred to in that subsection for the purpose of a recount under Part 14 or for the purpose of any other legal proceeding.

Section.Text: No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make a false statement in an application for registration and special ballot; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make a false statement in a declaration signed by him or her before an election officer or unit election officer.

Subsection.Text: At an election, no person shall, as a friend, assist under section 155 or 243.01, more than one elector for the purpose of marking a ballot.
No person who assists an elector under section 155 or 243.01 shall, directly or indirectly, disclose the name of the candidate for whom the elector voted or that candidate’s political affiliation.

Section.MarginalNote: Vouching for more than one person

Subsection.Text: No person shall vouch for more than one person at an election, except in the cases referred to in subsections 143(3.01), 161(2) and 169(2.01).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Voucher not qualified as elector, etc.
Subsection.Text: No person shall vouch for another person if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person who vouches is not qualified as an elector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person who vouches does not personally know the other person; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person who vouches does not reside in a polling division assigned to the same polling station as the polling division in which the other person resides or, in the cases referred to in subsections 143(3.01), 161(2) and 169(2.01), in a polling division in the other person’s electoral district or an adjacent electoral district.

Subsection.Text: No person who has been vouched for at an election shall vouch for another person at that election.

Section.Text: No person shall, in a polling station or in any place where voting at an election is taking place, influence or attempt to influence electors to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at the election.

Section.MarginalNote: Influencing electors — election officers and staff of returning officers
Section.Text: Subject to section 141, no election officer, unit election officer or member of the staff of a returning officer shall, while exercising their powers or performing their duties, influence or attempt to influence an elector to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at an election.

Subsection.Text: No person or entity referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (e) shall, during an election period, unduly influence an elector to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at the election:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an individual who is not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and who does not reside in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a corporation or entity incorporated, formed or otherwise organized outside Canada that does not carry on business in Canada or whose primary purpose in Canada during an election period is to influence electors during that period to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at the election;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a trade union that does not hold bargaining rights for employees in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign political party; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign government or an agent or mandatary of a foreign government.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), a person or entity unduly influences an elector to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at an election if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they knowingly incur any expense to directly promote or oppose a candidate in that election, a registered party that has endorsed a candidate in that election or the leader of such a registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one of the things done by them to influence the elector is an offence under an Act of Parliament or a regulation made under any such Act, or under an Act of the legislature of a province or a regulation made under any such Act.

Subsection.Text: For greater certainty, subsection (1) does not apply if the only thing done by the person or entity to influence the elector to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for the particular candidate or registered party, consists of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an expression of their opinion about the outcome or desired outcome of the election;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement by them that encourages the elector to vote or refrain from voting for any candidate or registered party in the election; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the transmission to the public through broadcasting, or through electronic or print media, of an editorial, a debate, a speech, an interview, a column, a letter, a commentary or news, regardless of the expense incurred in doing so, if no contravention of subsection 330(1) or (2) is involved in the transmission.

Subsection.Text: No person or entity shall act in collusion with a person or entity to whom subsection (1) applies for the purpose of contravening that subsection.

No person or entity shall sell any advertising space to a person or entity to whom subsection (1) applies for the purpose of enabling that person or entity to transmit an election advertising message or to cause an election advertising message to be transmitted.

Section.Text: No person shall interfere with, or attempt to interfere with, an elector who is marking a ballot or special ballot.
No person shall prevent or attempt to prevent an elector from voting at an election.

Subsection.Text: No person shall, during an election period, directly or indirectly, offer a bribe to influence an elector to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at the election.

No person shall, during an election period, accept or agree to accept a bribe that is offered to them to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at the election.

Section.Text: No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by intimidation or duress, compel or attempt to compel a person to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at an election; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by any pretence or contrivance, including by representing that the ballot or special ballot or the manner of voting at an election is not secret, influence or attempt to influence a person to vote or refrain from voting, or to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate or registered party, at an election.

Subsection.Text: Immediately after the close of a polling station, an election officer who is assigned to the polling station shall count the votes in the presence of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: another election officer who is assigned to the polling station; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any candidates or their representatives who are present or, if no candidates or representatives are present, at least two electors.

Subsection.Text: One of those election officers shall supply all the persons referred to in paragraph (1)(b) who are present and who request one with a tally sheet to keep their own score of the voting.
The election officer who counts the votes shall, in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: count the number of electors who voted, count the number of those to whom a certificate was given under subsection 161(4), make an entry at the end of the list of electors that states “The number of electors who voted at this election is (stating the number). Of these, the number of electors to whom a certificate was given under subsection 161(4) is (stating the number).”, sign the list and place the list in the envelope supplied for that purpose;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: count the spoiled ballots, place them in the envelope supplied for the purpose, indicate on the envelope the number of spoiled ballots, and seal it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: count the unused ballots that are not detached from the books of ballots, place them with the stubs of the used ballots in the envelope supplied for the purpose, indicate on the envelope the number of unused ballots, and seal it;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: total the number of electors indicated under paragraph (a) who voted and the numbers arrived at in paragraphs (b) and (c) in order to ascertain that all ballots that were provided by the returning officer are accounted for;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: open the ballot box and empty its contents onto a table; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: examine each ballot, show the ballot to each person who is present, and ask the election officer referred to in paragraph (1)(a) to make a note on the tally sheet beside the name of the candidate for whom the vote was cast for the purpose of arriving at the total number of votes cast for each candidate.

Subsection.Text: In examining the ballots, the election officer who counts the votes shall reject one

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that has not been supplied by him or her;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that has not been marked in a circle at the right of the candidates’ names;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that is void by virtue of section 76;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that has been marked in more than one circle at the right of the candidates’ names; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: on which there is any writing or mark by which the elector could be identified.

Subsection.Text: No ballot shall be rejected by reason only that an election officer placed on it any writing, number or mark, or failed to remove the counterfoil or to write the elector’s polling division number on the back of the ballot.

If a ballot is found with the counterfoil attached, the election officer who counts the votes shall, while concealing the number on it from all persons present and without examining it, remove and destroy the counterfoil.

Section.MarginalNote: Ballots not initialled by election officer
Section.Text: If the election officer who counts the votes determines that a ballot has not been initialed by an election officer, he or she shall, in the presence of the election officer referred to in paragraph 283(1)(a) and witnesses, initial and count the ballot if satisfied that all ballots that were provided by the returning officer have been accounted for, as described in paragraph 283(3)(d).

Subsection.Text: One of the election officers referred to in subsection 283(1) shall make a record, in the prescribed form, of every objection to a ballot made by a candidate or candidate’s representative, give a number to the objection, write that number on the ballot and initial it.

Every question that is raised by the objection shall be decided by the election officer who counts the votes, and the decision is subject to reversal only on a recount or on application under subsection 524(1).

The election officer who counts the votes shall prepare a statement of the vote, in the prescribed form, that sets out the number of votes in favour of each candidate and the number of rejected ballots and shall place the original statement and a copy of it in the separate envelopes supplied for the purpose.
The election officer shall give a copy of the statement of the vote to each of the candidates’ representatives present at the count.

One of the election officers referred to in subsection 283(1) shall place the ballots for each candidate into separate envelopes, write on each envelope the name of the candidate and the number of votes he or she received, and seal it. The election officers shall sign the seal on each envelope, and the witnesses may also sign them.
One of the election officers shall place into separate envelopes the rejected ballots, the registration certificates and the list of electors, and shall seal the envelopes.
One of the election officers shall seal in a large envelope supplied for the purpose

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the envelopes that contain the marked ballots for the candidates, any spoiled ballots, unused ballots or rejected ballots, and the official list of electors; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other election documents, except for the envelopes that contain the statements of the vote and the registration certificates.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Documents to be placed in the ballot box
Subsection.Text: The large envelope described in subsection (3) and the envelope that contains the copy of the statement of the vote shall be placed in the ballot box.
The ballot box shall be sealed with the seals provided by the Chief Electoral Officer.

Section.Text: One of the election officers referred to in subsection 283(1) shall place the form for each solemn declaration made under subsection 143(3) or paragraph 161(1)(b) or 169(2)(b) in an envelope supplied for the purpose.

Section.MarginalNote: Periodic statements of electors who voted
Section.Text: One of the election officers referred to in subsection 283(1) shall place a copy of each document prepared for the purpose of paragraph 162(i.1) in an envelope supplied for the purpose.

Section.MarginalNote: Counting of votes on polling day

Subsection.Text: At least two election officers who are assigned to an advance polling station and who are specified in accordance with the Chief Electoral Officer’s instructions shall, at the close of the polling stations on polling day, attend at the place mentioned in the notice of advance poll in subparagraph 172(a)(iii) to count the votes.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Application of rules for counting votes
Subsection.Text: Subsections 283(1) and (2), paragraphs 283(3)(e) and (f) and sections 284 to 288 apply with any necessary modifications to the counting of the votes of an advance poll except that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the application of paragraph 283(3)(e), the two or more election officers who are specified in accordance with the Chief Electoral Officer’s instructions shall open the ballot boxes and empty their contents onto a table; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the application of subsection 288(4), the large envelope and the envelope that contains the copy of the statement of the vote shall be placed in the ballot box used on the last day of advance polling.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), no person shall make a count of the votes cast at an advance poll before the close of voting hours on polling day.

The two or more election officers who are specified in accordance with the Chief Electoral Officer’s instructions may begin counting the votes cast at an advance poll one hour before the close of voting hours on polling day if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the returning officer who is responsible for the advance polling station has obtained the Chief Electoral Officer’s prior approval for the counting to begin;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the counting is done in accordance with the Chief Electoral Officer’s instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the counting is done in a manner that ensures the integrity of the vote; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the counting is done in the presence of any candidates or their representatives who are present or, if no candidates or representatives are present, at least two electors.

Heading.TitleText: Delivery of Ballot Boxes to Returning Officer

Section.MarginalNote: Sending ballot boxes and envelopes to returning officer
Section.Text: An election officer who is assigned to a polling station or an advance polling station shall, without delay after sealing the ballot box, send to the returning officer the box, with the envelope that contains the original statement of the vote, the envelope that contains the registration certificates, the envelope referred to in section 288.01 and, in the case of an election officer who is assigned to a polling station, the envelope referred to in section 288.1.
A returning officer shall — on the request of the candidate, his or her representative or a representative of the candidate’s party — provide him or her, after polling day, with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one copy of each statement of the vote in respect of the candidate’s electoral district; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one copy of the documents prepared under paragraph 162(i.1).

Section.Text: A returning officer, on the receipt of each ballot box, shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: take every precaution to prevent any other person, except the assistant returning officer, from having access to it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: examine and record the condition of the seals affixed to it and, if necessary, affix new seals.

Section.MarginalNote: List of persons who made solemn declaration
Section.Text: A returning officer, on the receipt of each envelope referred to in section 288.01, shall create a list of the names of all persons who made a solemn declaration under subsection 143(3) or paragraph 161(1)(b) or 169(2)(b) and shall include in the list the address of each of those persons.

Heading.Label: PART 13
Heading.TitleText: Validation of Results by the Returning Officer

Subsection.Text: After a returning officer receives all of the ballot boxes, he or she shall, at his or her office, in the presence of the assistant returning officer at the time indicated in paragraph 62(c), validate the results of the vote from the original statements of the vote and the information communicated under section 280.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Adjournment if ballot boxes or information not received
Subsection.Text: If, on the day fixed for the validation of the results as described in paragraph 62(c), a returning officer has not received all the ballot boxes or the information required by section 280, the returning officer shall adjourn the proceedings for not more than seven days.

If, on the day fixed for the proceedings by virtue of an adjournment under subsection (2), the returning officer has not, for any reason, received the ballot boxes or information referred to in that subsection, the returning officer may make further adjournments. The further adjournments may not exceed a total of two weeks.

Section.Text: Candidates and their representatives may attend the validation of the results, but if none of them is present, the returning officer shall ensure the presence of at least two electors until the validation is completed.

Section.MarginalNote: Opening ballot box in certain cases

Subsection.Text: If the original statement of the vote is missing, appears to contain an error, to be incomplete or to have been altered, or is disputed by a candidate or his or her representative, the returning officer may open the ballot box and the envelope that contains the copy of the statement of the vote or, if that copy is missing, the large envelope.

If a copy of the statement of the vote is not found or is not useful for the purpose of validating the results, the returning officer may use the information that is written on the envelopes that contain the ballots for that purpose.
The returning officer shall not open an envelope that appears to contain ballots.
If the returning officer opens the large envelope, he or she shall place its contents into another envelope, seal that envelope and initial the seal.

Section.MarginalNote: Loss or destruction of ballot boxes

Subsection.Text: If a ballot box has been destroyed or is missing, the returning officer shall ascertain the cause of the destruction or loss and shall complete the validation of the results from the original copy of the statement of the vote in the same manner as if he or she had received the ballot box.
If the returning officer is unable to obtain either the original statement of the vote or the ballot box, he or she

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall ascertain, by any evidence that he or she is able to obtain, the total number of votes cast for each candidate at the polling stations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for ascertaining the total number of votes under paragraph (a), may summon any election officer or other person to appear before him or her at a fixed date and time and to bring with them all necessary documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: may question the election officer or other person respecting the matter in question and, if necessary, ask them to make a solemn declaration in respect of the matter.

Subsection.Text: If paragraph (2)(b) applies, the returning officer shall give notice to the candidates for that electoral district of the date and time fixed for the appearance.
Every person to whom a summons is directed under paragraph (2)(b) shall obey it.

Section.Text: Without delay after the validation of the results, the returning officer shall prepare a certificate in the prescribed form that sets out the number of votes cast for each candidate, and shall deliver the original of the certificate to the Chief Electoral Officer and a copy of it to each candidate or his or her representative. In the case described in section 296, the certificate shall indicate the number of votes that have been ascertained to have been cast for each candidate.
After the close of an election, each returning officer shall dispose of the ballot boxes as instructed by the Chief Electoral Officer.

Subsection.Text: In this Part, judge means a judge who sits in the electoral district where the results are validated.
A judge who is authorized by sections 300 to 309 to act may act, to the extent authorized, within or outside his or her judicial district.

Section.MarginalNote: Request by returning officer for recount

Subsection.Text: If the difference between the number of votes cast for the candidate with the most votes and the number cast for any other candidate is less than 1/1000 of the votes cast, the returning officer shall make a request to a judge for a recount within four days after the results are validated.
The returning officer shall notify each candidate or his or her official agent in writing of the request for a recount.
The judge shall fix the date for the recount to be conducted within four days after he or she receives the request.
The returning officer shall attend the recount and shall bring all relevant election materials including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ballot boxes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the statements of the vote used to validate the results; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all ballots cast and statements of the vote made in accordance with Part 11.

Subsection.Text: An elector may, within four days after the day on which a returning officer issues a certificate under section 297 and after notifying the returning officer in writing, apply to a judge for a recount.
The returning officer shall notify each candidate or his or her official agent in writing of the application for a recount.
The judge shall fix a date for a recount if it appears, on the affidavit of a credible witness, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an election officer has incorrectly counted or rejected any ballots, or has written an incorrect number on the statement of the vote for the votes cast for a candidate; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the returning officer has incorrectly added up the results set out in the statements of the vote.

Subsection.Text: The applicant shall deposit with the clerk or prothonotary of the court the sum of $250 as security for the costs of the candidate who obtained the largest number of votes.

The date fixed for the recount shall be within four days after the judge receives the application. The judge shall summon the returning officer to attend and to bring the relevant ballot boxes and statements of the vote together with the ballots that were counted, and the statements that were completed, under Part 11.

The judge shall notify each candidate or his or her official agent in writing of the time and place fixed for the recount. The judge may decide that service of the notice will be substitutional, by mail or posting or in any other manner.
A returning officer to whom a summons is directed under subsection (4) shall obey it and shall be present throughout the recount.

Section.Text: If a judge receives more than one application for a recount for more than one electoral district, the recounts shall be conducted in the order in which the judge receives the applications.

Subsection.Text: The judge shall conduct the recount by adding the number of votes reported in the statements of the vote or by counting the valid ballots or all of the ballots returned by election officers or the Chief Electoral Officer.

If a recount of all of the ballots returned is required, the judge may open the sealed envelopes that contain the used and counted, unused, rejected and spoiled ballots. The judge shall not open any envelopes that appear to contain other documents or refer to any other election documents.
In the case of a recount conducted by counting the valid ballots or all of the ballots returned by election officers or the Chief Electoral Officer, the procedure set out in Schedule 4 applies.

For the purpose of arriving at the facts with respect to a missing ballot box or statement of the vote, the judge has all the powers of a returning officer with regard to the attendance and examination of witnesses who, in case of non-attendance, are subject to the same consequences as in the case of refusal or neglect to attend on the summons of a returning officer.

For the purpose of conducting a recount, a judge has the power to summon any election officer as a witness and to require him or her to give evidence on oath and, for that purpose, has the same power that is vested in any court of record.
Subject to the approval of the Chief Electoral Officer, a judge may retain the services of support staff to assist in the performance of his or her duties under this Part.

Section.Text: The judge shall, as far as practicable, proceed continuously with a recount, except for necessary breaks and, unless the judge orders otherwise, between 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m.

Subsection.Text: During a break described in section 305, the judge or any other person who has possession of ballots and other election documents shall keep them sealed in parcels, and the seal shall be signed by the judge and may be signed by any other person in attendance.
The judge shall personally supervise the parcelling and sealing of ballots and documents at a recount and take all necessary precautions for their security.

Section.Text: Except in a case referred to in section 300, a judge may at any time terminate a recount on request in writing by the person who applied for the recount.
At the conclusion of a recount, the judge shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: seal the ballots in a separate envelope for each polling station and without delay prepare a certificate in the prescribed form that sets out the number of votes cast for each candidate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: deliver the original of the certificate to the returning officer and a copy of it to each candidate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: return to the returning officer the election documents or election materials brought under subsection 300(4) or 301(4) for the purpose of the recount; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: deliver to the returning officer the reports created in the course of the recount.

Subsection.Text: If a recount does not alter the result of the vote so as to affect the return, the judge shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: order the costs of the candidate for whom the largest number of votes have been cast to be paid by the person who applied for the recount; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: tax those costs, following as closely as possible the tariff of costs allowed with respect to proceedings in the court in which the judge ordinarily presides.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Disposal of deposit and right of action for balance
Subsection.Text: The money deposited as security for costs shall, as far as is necessary, be paid out to the candidate in whose favour costs are awarded under subsection (1) and, if the deposit is insufficient to cover the costs, the party in whose favour the costs are awarded has their action for the balance.

After a recount, a candidate may make an application to the Chief Electoral Officer for reimbursement of his or her costs in respect of the recount, setting out the amount and nature of the costs and whether they were actually and reasonably incurred.

On receipt of an application under subsection (1), the Chief Electoral Officer shall determine the costs, and shall make a request for reimbursement to the Receiver General, up to a maximum of $500 for each day or part of a day during which the judge conducted the recount.
The Receiver General, on receipt of a request for reimbursement from the Chief Electoral Officer, shall pay to the candidate the amount requested from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Heading.TitleText: Failure of Judge to Conduct Recount

Subsection.Text: If a judge does not comply with the provisions of sections 300 to 309, an aggrieved party may, within eight days after the failure to comply, make application for an order under subsection (3)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the Province of Ontario, to a judge of the Superior Court of Justice;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the Province of Quebec, New Brunswick or Alberta, Yukon, the Northwest Territories or Nunavut, to a judge of the Court of Appeal of the Province or Territory;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the Province of Nova Scotia, British Columbia or Prince Edward Island, to a judge of the Supreme Court of the Province;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the Province of Manitoba or Saskatchewan, to a judge of the Court of Queen’s Bench for the Province; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador, to a judge of the Trial Division of the Supreme Court of Newfoundland and Labrador.

Subsection.Text: An application under subsection (1) may be made on affidavit, which need not be entitled in any matter or cause, that sets out the facts relating to the failure to comply.
The judge to whom an application is made under subsection (1) shall, if it appears that there was a failure to comply, make an order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fixing the time, within the following eight days, and place to hear the application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: directing the attendance of all parties interested at that time and place; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: giving directions for the service of the order, and of any affidavit on which it was granted, on the judge alleged to have failed to comply and on any other interested party.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Affidavits may be filed in reply
Subsection.Text: The judge complained of and any interested party may file in the office of the clerk, registrar or prothonotary of the court of the judge to whom the application is made affidavits in reply to those filed by the applicant and shall provide the applicant with copies of them on demand.
After hearing the judge complained of and any other parties, the judge to whom the application was made or another judge of the same court

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall make an order dismissing the application or ordering the judge in default to comply with the requirements of this Act in respect of the recount; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may make an order with respect to costs.

Subsection.Text: A judge found to be in default shall without delay comply with an order made under subsection (1).
Remedies for the recovery of costs awarded under paragraph (1)(b) are the same as for costs in ordinary cases in the same court.

The returning officer, without delay after the sixth day that follows the completion of the validation of results or, if there is a recount, without delay after receiving the certificate referred to in section 308, shall declare elected the candidate who obtained the largest number of votes by completing the return of the writ in the prescribed form on the back of the writ.
If there is an equality of votes between the candidates with the largest number of votes, the returning officer shall indicate that on the return of the writ.
On completing the return of the writ, the returning officer shall without delay send to the Chief Electoral Officer all election documents in his or her possession together with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a report of the returning officer’s proceedings in the prescribed form including his or her comments with respect to the state of the election documents received from election officers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a summary, in the prescribed form, of the number of votes cast for each candidate at each polling station; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all other documents that were used at the election, including documents prepared under paragraph 162(i.1).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Report re: disappearance of ballot box, etc.
Subsection.Text: In any case arising under section 296, the returning officer shall mention specially in the report the circumstances accompanying the disappearance of the ballot boxes or the lack of any statement of the vote, and the mode by which the returning officer ascertained the number of votes cast for each candidate.

Section.MarginalNote: Duplicate of return to each candidate

Subsection.Text: The returning officer shall forward a copy of the return of the writ to each candidate.
A premature return of the writ is deemed not to have reached the Chief Electoral Officer until it should have reached the Chief Electoral Officer in due course.
The Chief Electoral Officer shall, if necessary, send back the return of the writ and any or all of the related election documents to the returning officer for completion or correction.

Where, at the time of the issue of an order under section 311 or 312, the returning officer for the electoral district in respect of which the order is made has made a return of the writ under section 314, the Chief Electoral Officer shall, on being provided with a certified copy of the order, send back to the returning officer all election documents required for use at the recount.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Duties of returning officer on recount
Subsection.Text: On receiving a judge’s certificate with respect to the result of a recount, the returning officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the result of the recount is that a person other than the person named in the original return is to be returned, make a substitute return of the writ; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the result of the recount is to confirm the return, send the papers back to the Chief Electoral Officer without delay and not make a substitute return of the writ.

Subsection.Text: A substitute return made under paragraph (2)(a) has the effect of cancelling the original return.

Section.MarginalNote: Procedure on receipt of return by Chief Electoral Officer
Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer, on receiving each return of the writ, shall, in the order in which the return is received,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: indicate, in a book kept by the Chief Electoral Officer for the purpose, that he or she has received it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: publish in the Canada Gazette the name of the candidate who was declared elected.

Section.Text: If the return of the writ indicates an equality of votes between the candidates with the largest number of votes, the Chief Electoral Officer shall without delay

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prepare and send to the Speaker of the House of Commons or, if none, two members of the House or two candidates who have been declared elected, as the case may be, a report stating that no candidate was declared elected in the electoral district because of the equality of votes; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: publish in the Canada Gazette

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the names of the candidates between whom there was an equality of votes, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: notice that, as no candidate was declared elected in the electoral district because of the equality of votes, a by-election will be conducted under subsection 29(1.1) of the Parliament of Canada Act.

Section.Text: The definitions in this section apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: network means a network as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Broadcasting Act, but does not include a temporary network operation as defined in that subsection. (réseau)

network operator means a person or undertaking to which permission has been granted by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission to form and operate a network. (exploitant de réseau)

online platform includes an Internet site or Internet application whose owner or operator, in the course of their commercial activities, sells, directly or indirectly, advertising space on the site or application to persons or groups. (plateforme en ligne)

prime time, in the case of a radio station, means the time between the hours of 6 a.m. and 9 a.m., noon and 2 p.m. and 4 p.m. and 7 p.m., and, in the case of a television station, means the hours between 6 p.m. and midnight. (heures de grande écoute)

Section.Text: A candidate or registered party, or a person acting on their behalf, who causes election advertising to be conducted shall mention in or on the message that its transmission was authorized by the official agent of the candidate or by the registered agent of the party, as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: No landlord or person acting on their behalf may prohibit a tenant from displaying election advertising posters on the premises to which the lease relates and no condominium corporation or any of its agents may prohibit the owner of a condominium unit from displaying election advertising posters on the premises of his or her unit.

Despite subsection (1), a landlord, person, condominium corporation or agent referred to in that subsection may set reasonable conditions relating to the size or type of election advertising posters that may be displayed on the premises and may prohibit the display of election advertising posters in common areas of the building in which the premises are found.
No person shall transmit election advertising to the public in an electoral district on polling day before the close of all of the polling stations in the electoral district.

The transmission to the public of a notice of an event that the leader of a registered party intends to attend or an invitation to meet or hear the leader of a registered party is not election advertising for the purpose of subsection (1).
For the purpose of subsection (1), a person includes a registered party and a group within the meaning of Part 17.

Section.Text: Subsection 323(1) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the transmission of a message that was transmitted to the public on what is commonly known as the Internet before the blackout period described in that subsection and that was not changed during that period; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the distribution during that period of pamphlets or the posting of messages on signs, posters or banners.

Section.MarginalNote: Prohibition — prevention or impairment of transmission
