Paragraph.Text: any cost incurred, or non-monetary contribution received, by a leadership contestant, to the extent that the property or service that the cost was incurred for or that was received as a non-monetary contribution is used to directly promote or oppose a leadership contestant during a leadership contest; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any acceptance by a leadership contestant of a provision of goods or services that is permitted under paragraph 364(2)(c), to the extent that the goods or services are used to directly promote or oppose a leadership contestant during a leadership contest.

Subsection.Text: Expenses for a fundraising activity, other than expenses referred to in paragraphs (3)(a) and (b) that are related to that activity, are not leadership contest expenses under subsection (1).
A leadership contest expense includes a cost incurred for, a non-monetary contribution in relation to, or a provision of goods and services in relation to,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the production of advertising or promotional material;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the distribution, broadcast or publication of such material in any media or by any other means during the leadership contest, including by the use of a capital asset;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the payment of remuneration and expenses to or on behalf of a person for their services as a financial agent or in any other capacity;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: securing a meeting space or the supply of light refreshments at meetings;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any product or service provided by a government, a Crown corporation or any other public agency; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of surveys or research during a leadership contest.

Subsection.Text: In this section, cost incurred means an expense that is incurred by a leadership contestant, whether it is paid or unpaid.

Section.Text: A litigation expense of a leadership contestant is an expense of the contestant related to an application to a judge made under this Part, including an expense related to any appeal or judicial review arising from the application.

Subsection.Text: A leadership contestant’s personal expenses include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: childcare expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: expenses relating to the provision of care for a person with a physical or mental incapacity for whom the contestant normally provides such care; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a contestant who has a disability, additional expenses that are related to the disability.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exclusions — travel and living expenses, etc.
Subsection.Text: Neither litigation expenses nor travel and living expenses are personal expenses of a leadership contestant.

If an expense of $50 or more was incurred under this Act by or on behalf of a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant and paid by an agent or other person authorized under this Act to pay such an expense, the agent or other person shall keep a copy of the invoice prepared by the person who provided the good or service to which the expense relates setting out the nature of the expense together with proof that it was paid.

If an expense of less than $50 was incurred and paid as described in subsection (1), the person who made the payment shall keep a record of the nature of the expense together with proof that it was paid.
A person may pay a petty expense incurred for office supplies, postage, courier services and other incidental expenses under the written authorization of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a registered agent of a registered party, as an expense incurred on behalf of the registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an electoral district agent of a registered association, as an expense incurred on behalf of the association;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the financial agent of a nomination contestant, as a nomination campaign expense;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the official agent of a candidate, as an electoral campaign expense for the candidate; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a leadership campaign agent of a leadership contestant, as a leadership campaign expense.

Subsection.Text: The written authorization referred to in subsection (1) shall specify a maximum amount for the total of petty expenses that the person is authorized to pay.

A person who is authorized to pay a petty expense shall provide the agent who authorized it with a statement of payments that the person made and the documentation referred to in section 380 within three months after

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a registered party, the day on which it is incurred;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a registered association, the day on which it is incurred;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a nomination contestant, the day on which it is incurred;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a candidate, polling day; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a leadership contestant, the day on which it is incurred.

Subsection.Text: No person who is authorized to pay petty expenses shall pay, in total, more than the maximum amount of petty expenses that they are authorized to pay.

Section.MarginalNote: Publication of electoral campaign returns and election expenses returns

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall, in the manner that he or she considers appropriate, publish the original election expenses returns of registered parties and electoral campaign returns of candidates and any corrected or revised versions of those returns

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an original return, within one year after the issue of a writ for an election;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a corrected or revised version of a return, as soon as feasible after he or she receives it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a document referred to in subsection 477.59(10), (11), (12) or (15), or a corrected or revised version of such a document, as soon as feasible after he or she receives it.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall publish the following, as soon as feasible after receiving them, in the manner that he or she considers appropriate:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the financial transactions returns of registered parties and registered associations, and any corrected or revised versions of those returns;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nomination campaign returns of nomination contestants, any document referred to in subsection 476.75(10), (11), (12) or (15), and any corrected or revised versions of those returns or documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the leadership campaign returns of leadership contestants, any document referred to in subsection 478.8(10), (11), (12) or (15), any corrected or revised versions of those returns or documents, the returns in respect of contributions required under section 478.81, and any statements containing information with respect to contributions referred to in paragraph 478.3(2)(d).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Summary of return on candidates’ election expenses
Subsection.Text: As soon as feasible after receiving an electoral campaign return, any document referred to in subsection 477.59(10), (11), (12) or (15) or any corrected or revised version of those returns or documents for each candidate in an electoral district, the Chief Electoral Officer shall, in the manner that he or she considers appropriate, publish a summary report that includes the maximum election expenses allowed for the electoral district and, for each candidate,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the total election expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (a.1)
Paragraph.Text: the total litigation expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (a.2)
Paragraph.Text: the total travel and living expenses that are related to travel and sojourns during the election period;

Paragraph.Label: (a.3)
Paragraph.Text: the total accessibility expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the total personal expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of contributors and the total amount of contributions received;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the official agent;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the auditor; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, an indication that the auditor’s report on a return was qualified.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Publication of return of deregistered parties
Subsection.Text: As soon as feasible after receiving a financial transactions return under subparagraph 420(a)(i) from a deregistered political party, the Chief Electoral Officer shall publish it in the manner that he or she considers appropriate.

Section.Text: Before April 1 in each year, the Chief Electoral Officer shall cause to be published in the Canada Gazette an inflation adjustment factor that is in effect for a period of one year beginning on that date. It shall be a fraction with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a numerator that is the annual average Consumer Price Index, as published by Statistics Canada under the authority of the Statistics Act, for the calendar year immediately before that date, calculated on the basis of 1992 being equal to 100; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a denominator that is 108.6, which is the annual average Consumer Price Index, as published by Statistics Canada under the authority of the Statistics Act, for 1998, calculated on the basis of 1992 being equal to 100.

Subsection.Text: In this Division, regulated fundraising event means an event

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that is organized for the financial benefit of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a registered party that is represented in the House of Commons on the day the event occurs or, if Parliament is dissolved, on the date of dissolution, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a registered association, nomination contestant, candidate or leadership contestant of a registered party described in subparagraph (i); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is attended by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a leader, interim leader or leadership contestant of the registered party for whose financial benefit the event is organized or the registered party described in subparagraph (a)(ii), or a minister of the Crown or minister of state who is a member of the registered party for whose financial benefit the event is organized or the registered party described in that subparagraph, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: at least one person who, in order to attend it, is required

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: to have made a contribution or contributions of a total amount of more than $200 to the registered party or any of its registered associations, nomination contestants, candidates or leadership contestants, or to any combination of them, or to be the guest of a person who has made such a contribution or contributions, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: to have paid more than $200, the amount including a contribution to the registered party or any of its registered associations, nomination contestants, candidates or leadership contestants, or to any combination of them, or to be the guest of a person who has made such a payment.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exclusion — conventions and leadership contestant debates
Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), a regulated fundraising event does not include a convention, including a leadership convention, of a registered party referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(i), or a leadership contestants’ debate.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Inclusion — fundraising events that are part of conventions
Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (2), a regulated fundraising event includes an event that is part of a convention referred to in that subsection if the event is attended by at least one person who, in order to attend it, is required

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to make a contribution or contributions — in addition to any amount that they were required to pay to attend the convention — of a total amount of more than $200 to the registered party or any of its registered associations, nomination contestants, candidates or leadership contestants, or to any combination of them, or to be the guest of a person who has made such a contribution or contributions; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to pay more than $200 — in addition to any amount that they were required to pay to attend the convention — to attend the event, the amount including a contribution to the registered party or any of its registered associations, nomination contestants, candidates or leadership contestants, or to any combination of them, or to be the guest of a person who has made such a payment.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (3), a regulated fundraising event does not include any event that is part of a convention referred to in subsection (2) and that is organized to express appreciation for persons who have made a contribution to the registered party or any of its registered associations, nomination contestants, candidates or leadership contestants.

Section.MarginalNote: Regulated fundraising event organized by registered party

Subsection.Text: If a registered party organizes all or part of a regulated fundraising event for its own financial benefit or for the financial benefit of one of its registered associations, nomination contestants, candidates or leadership contestants, the registered party shall publish the information set out in subsection (2) in a prominent location on its Internet site for the period beginning five days before the day the regulated fundraising event takes place and ending at the time the event starts.
The information to be published under subsection (1) and provided under subsection (3) is the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and location of the regulated fundraising event;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each entity or person referred to in paragraph 384.1(1)(a) for whose financial benefit the event is organized;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each person referred to in subparagraph 384.1(1)(b)(i) who will be attending the event;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the total amount of contributions that a person will be required to have made, or the amount that they will be required to have paid, in order to attend the event; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the contact information of an individual who may be contacted and from whom further information about the event may be obtained.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Regulated fundraising event not organized by registered party
Subsection.Text: If a regulated fundraising event is organized entirely by one or more persons or entities other than the registered party for whose financial benefit the event is organized, or for the financial benefit of whose registered association, nomination contestant, candidate or leadership contestant the event is organized, each person or entity that organizes the event or any part of it shall provide the information set out in subsection (2) to the registered party in time for the registered party to be able to publish the information as required under subsection (4).

If at least one person or entity referred to in subsection (3) complies with the obligation under that subsection — to provide information to the registered party in time for the registered party to be able to publish it — the registered party shall publish that information in a prominent location on its Internet site for the period beginning five days before the day the regulated fundraising event takes place and ending at the time the event starts.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Registered party to notify Chief Electoral Officer
Subsection.Text: If a registered party is required to publish information under subsection (1) or (4), it shall also notify the Chief Electoral Officer of the regulated fundraising event no later than five days before the day the event takes place.

If a registered party referred to in subsection (1) or (4) becomes aware, after publishing information under this section, of any change to that information, the registered party shall replace the old information on its Internet site with the new information as soon as feasible after becoming aware of the change.

If a person or entity referred to in subsection (3) becomes aware, after providing information to a registered party under this section, of any change to that information, the person or entity shall provide the new information to the registered party as soon as feasible after becoming aware of the change.

If new information is provided to a registered party under subsection (6), the registered party shall replace the old information on its Internet site with the new information as soon as feasible after being provided with it.
Subsections (1) to (7) do not apply in respect of a regulated fundraising event that takes place during the election period of a general election.

Section.MarginalNote: Report on regulated fundraising event organized by registered party

Subsection.Text: If a registered party organizes all or part of a regulated fundraising event for its own financial benefit or for the financial benefit of one of its registered associations, nomination contestants, candidates or leadership contestants, the registered party’s chief agent shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with a report, in the prescribed form, on the regulated fundraising event.
Subject to subsection (3), the report referred to in subsection (1) shall set out the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and location of the regulated fundraising event;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each entity or person referred to in paragraph 384.1(1)(a) for whose financial benefit the event was organized;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each person referred to in subparagraph 384.1(1)(b)(i) who attended the event;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each person — other than any person referred to in paragraph (c) — who attended the event, along with the name of their municipality or its equivalent, their province and their postal code;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the total amount of contributions that a person was required to have made, or the amount that they were required to have paid, in order to attend the event; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each person or entity that organized the event or any part of it.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Information not to be included in report
Subsection.Text: The registered party’s chief agent shall not include in the report referred to in subsection (1) the name of any of the following persons who attended the regulated fundraising event, nor the name of their municipality or its equivalent, their province or their postal code:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any person who was under 18 years of age on the day on which the event took place;

Paragraph.Label: (a.1)
Paragraph.Text: any person who attended the event solely to assist a person with a disability;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person who attended the event solely because they were employed in the organization of the event;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any of the following persons who attended the event solely in the course of their employment:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an employee or other representative of any media organization, as well as any freelance journalist, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a member of the support staff, including security staff, of any person referred to in subparagraph 384.1(1)(b)(i) who attended the event; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any person who attended the event solely in order to provide volunteer labour.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Regulated fundraising event not organized by registered party
Subsection.Text: If a regulated fundraising event is organized entirely by one or more persons or entities other than the registered party for whose financial benefit the event is organized, or for the financial benefit of whose registered association, nomination contestant, candidate or leadership contestant the event is organized, each person or entity that organizes the event or any part of it shall, subject to subsection (5), provide the information set out in subsection (2) to the registered party in time for the registered party’s chief agent to be able to provide the Chief Electoral Officer with a report on the event as required under subsection (6).

If a person or entity referred to in subsection (4) becomes aware, after providing information to a registered party under that subsection or this subsection, of any change to that information, the person or entity shall provide the new information to the registered party as soon as feasible after becoming aware of the change.

No person or entity referred to in subsection (4) or (4.1) shall include in the information provided to the registered party under that subsection the name of any person referred to in paragraphs (3)(a) to (d) who attended the regulated fundraising event, nor the name of their municipality or its equivalent, their province or their postal code.

If at least one person or entity referred to in subsection (4) complies with the obligation under that subsection — to provide information to the registered party in time for the registered party’s chief agent to be able to provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the report — that chief agent shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with a report, in the prescribed form, on the regulated fundraising event setting out that information.

The registered party’s chief agent shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the reports referred to in subsections (1) and (6) within 30 days after the day the regulated fundraising event takes place.
Subsections (1) to (6.1) do not apply in respect of a regulated fundraising event that takes place during the election period of a general election.

A registered party’s chief agent shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with a single report, in the prescribed form, on all the regulated fundraising events that were held during the election period for a general election and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all or part of which were organized by the registered party for its own financial benefit or for the financial benefit of one of its registered associations, nomination contestants, candidates or leadership contestants; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of which at least one person or entity that organized the event or any part of it complied with the obligation under subsection (9).

Subsection.Text: The registered party’s chief agent shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the report referred to in subsection (8) within 60 days after polling day at the general election.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Regulated fundraising event not organized by registered party
Subsection.Text: If a regulated fundraising event that was held during the election period for a general election was organized entirely by one or more persons or entities other than the registered party for whose financial benefit the event was organized, or for the financial benefit of whose registered association, nomination contestant, candidate or leadership contestant the event was organized, each person or entity that organized the event or any part of it shall, subject to subsection (10), provide the information set out in subsection (2) to the registered party in time for the registered party’s chief agent to be able to provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the report as required under subsection (8).

If a person or entity referred to in subsection (9) becomes aware, after providing information to a registered party under that subsection or this subsection, of any change to that information, the person or entity shall provide the new information to the registered party as soon as feasible after becoming aware of the change.

No person or entity referred to in subsection (9) or (9.1) shall include in the information provided to the registered party under that subsection the name of any person referred to in paragraphs (3)(a) to (d) who attended the regulated fundraising event, nor the name of their municipality or its equivalent, their province or their postal code.
Subject to subsection (12), the report referred to in subsection (8) shall set out the information referred to in subsection (2) for each regulated fundraising event referred to in subsection (8).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Information not to be included in report
Subsection.Text: The registered party’s chief agent shall not include in the report referred to in subsection (8), in respect of a given regulated fundraising event, the name of any person referred to in paragraphs (3)(a) to (d) who attended that event, nor the name of their municipality or its equivalent, their province or their postal code.

The Chief Electoral Officer shall publish reports provided under subsections (1), (6) and (8), and any corrected or revised versions of those reports, as soon as feasible after receiving them, in the manner that he or she considers appropriate.

Section.Text: If a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant receives a contribution in respect of a regulated fundraising event in respect of which section 384.2 or 384.3 is not complied with, the chief agent of the registered party, the financial agent of the registered association, the official agent of the candidate or the financial agent of the nomination contestant or leadership contestant, as the case may be, shall, within 30 days after becoming aware of the non-compliance, return the contribution unused to the contributor or, if that is not possible, pay the amount of it — or, in the case of a non-monetary contribution, an amount of money equal to its commercial value — to the Chief Electoral Officer, who shall forward that amount to the Receiver General.

Heading.TitleText: Corrections, Revisions and Extended Reporting Periods

Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may correct a report referred to in subsection 384.3(1), (6) or (8) if the correction does not materially affect its substance.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer, on the written application of a registered party’s chief agent or, if the chief agent is absent or unable to perform their duties, its leader, shall authorize the extension of the period referred to in subsection 384.3(6.1) or (8.1) unless he or she is satisfied that the chief agent’s failure to provide the report was deliberate or was the result of the chief agent’s failure to exercise due diligence.
The application may be made within the period referred to in subsection 384.3(6.1) or (8.1) or within two weeks after the end of that period.

Section.MarginalNote: Corrections or revisions — Chief Electoral Officer

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer, on the written application of a registered party’s chief agent or, if the chief agent is absent or unable to perform their duties, its leader, shall authorize the correction or revision of a report referred to in subsection 384.3(1), (6) or (8) if he or she is satisfied by the evidence submitted by the applicant that the correction or revision is necessary in order for the requirements of this Act to be complied with.
The application shall be made immediately after the applicant becomes aware of the need for correction or revision.

The applicant shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the corrected or revised version of the report within 30 days after the day on which the correction or revision is authorized or within any extension of that period authorized under subsection (4) or (5).

The Chief Electoral Officer, on the written application of the applicant made within two weeks after the end of the 30-day period referred to in subsection (3), shall authorize the extension of that period, unless he or she is satisfied that the applicant’s failure to provide the corrected or revised version of the report was deliberate or was the result of the applicant’s failure to exercise due diligence.

The Chief Electoral Officer, on the written application of the applicant made within two weeks after the end of an extension authorized under subsection (4) or under this subsection, shall authorize the further extension of that period, unless he or she is satisfied that the applicant’s failure to provide the corrected or revised version of the report was deliberate or was the result of the applicant’s failure to exercise due diligence.
The chief agent of a registered party or, if the chief agent is absent or unable to perform their duties, its leader, may apply to a judge for an order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: authorizing an extension referred to in subsection 384.6(1); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: authorizing a correction or revision referred to in subsection 384.7(1).

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: The applicant shall notify the Chief Electoral Officer that the application has been made.

Subsection.Text: The application may be made

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under paragraph (1)(a), within two weeks after, as the case may be,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if an application for an extension is not made to the Chief Electoral Officer within the period referred to in subsection 384.6(2), the end of the two-week period referred to in that subsection,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the rejection of an application for an extension made in accordance with section 384.6, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the end of the extended period referred to in subsection 384.6(1); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under paragraph (1)(b), within two weeks after the rejection of an application for a correction or revision made in accordance with section 384.7.

Subsection.Text: The judge shall grant an order authorizing an extension unless the judge is satisfied that the chief agent’s failure to provide the required report was deliberate or was the result of the chief agent’s failure to exercise due diligence.

The judge shall grant an order authorizing a correction or revision if the judge is satisfied by the evidence submitted by the applicant that the correction or revision is necessary in order for the requirements of this Act to be complied with.
The order may require that the applicant satisfy any condition that the judge considers necessary for carrying out the purposes of this Act.
The leader of a political party may apply to the Chief Electoral Officer for the political party to become a registered party.
The application for registration shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the political party’s full name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the party’s short-form name, or its abbreviation, if any, that is to be shown in election documents;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the party’s logo, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the party’s leader and a copy of the party’s resolution to appoint the leader, certified by the leader and another officer of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the address of the party’s office where records are maintained and to which communications may be addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the names and addresses of the party’s officers and their signed consent to act in that capacity;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the party’s auditor and their signed consent to act in that capacity;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the party’s chief agent and their signed consent to act in that capacity;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the names and addresses of 250 electors and their declarations in the prescribed form that they are members of the party and support the party’s application for registration;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the leader’s declaration in the prescribed form that, having considered all of the factors — including those described in subsection 521.1(5) — relevant to determining the party’s purposes, one of the party’s fundamental purposes is to participate in public affairs by endorsing one or more of its members as candidates and supporting their election;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the party’s policy for the protection of personal information, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement indicating the types of personal information that the party collects and how it collects that information,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement indicating how the party protects personal information under its control,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement indicating how the party uses personal information under its control and under what circumstances that personal information may be sold to any person or entity,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement indicating the training concerning the collection and use of personal information to be given to any employee of the party who could have access to personal information under the party’s control,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement indicating the party’s practices concerning

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the collection and use of personal information created from online activity, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and contact information of a person to whom concerns regarding the party’s policy for the protection of personal information can be addressed; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the address of the page — accessible to the public — on the party’s Internet site where its policy for the protection of personal information is published under subsection (4).

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may establish a maximum length for a political party’s short-form name that is to be shown in election documents.

To confirm that the purpose referred to in paragraph (2)(j) is one of the party’s fundamental purposes, the Chief Electoral Officer may ask the party’s leader to provide any relevant information, including information about the factors described in subsection 521.1(5).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Publication of policy for the protection of personal information
Subsection.Text: A political party shall publish on its Internet site its policy for the protection of personal information referred to in paragraph (2)(k) before its leader applies under this section for the party to become a registered party.

Section.MarginalNote: Policy for the protection of personal information — parties already registered, etc.

Subsection.Text: Within three months after the day on which this section comes into force, the leader of a political party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the party’s policy for the protection of personal information referred to in paragraph 385(2)(k) and the Internet address referred to in paragraph 385(2)(l), if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before the day on which this section comes into force, the leader of the party has applied under section 385 for the party to become a registered party but, as of that day, the Chief Electoral Officer has not yet informed the leader under subsection 389(1) whether or not the party is eligible for registration under section 387; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the day on which this section comes into force, the party is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an eligible party, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a registered party.

Subsection.Text: If the leader of the political party does not comply with subsection (1), then

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a party referred to in paragraph (1)(a), the party is not eligible for registration under section 387;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a party referred to in subparagraph (1)(b)(i), the party may not become a registered party under section 390; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a party referred to in subparagraph (1)(b)(ii), the Chief Electoral Officer shall implement the procedure for non-voluntary deregistration set out in sections 415, 416 and 418.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deemed inclusion in application for registration
Subsection.Text: If the leader of a political party provides the Chief Electoral Officer with the policy and the address referred to in subsection (1) in compliance with that subsection, or in compliance with section 415, then the policy and the address are deemed, as of the day on which they are provided, to be included in the application for registration referred to in subsection 385(2) in respect of the party.
Despite the definition personal information in subsection 2(1), for the purposes of this section, personal information means information about an identifiable individual.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Collection, use, disclosure, retention and disposal
Subsection.Text: In order to participate in public affairs by endorsing one or more of its members as candidates and supporting their election, any registered party or eligible party, as well as any person or organization acting on the party’s behalf, including the party’s candidates, electoral district associations, officers, agents, employees, volunteers and representatives, may, subject to this Act and any other applicable federal Act, collect, use, disclose, retain and dispose of personal information in accordance with the party’s privacy policy.

The purpose of this section is to provide for a national, uniform, exclusive and complete regime applicable to registered parties and eligible parties respecting their collection, use, disclosure, retention and disposal of personal information.

Section.Text: A leader who has made an application under subsection 385(1) may withdraw it at any time before registration by sending a signed request to that effect to the Chief Electoral Officer.
A political party whose leader has made an application under subsection 385(1) becomes eligible for registration if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo does not

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: so resemble the name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo of a registered party or an eligible party that it would, in the Chief Electoral Officer’s opinion, likely be confused with it, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: include the word “independent” or a word that so resembles “independent” that it would, in the Chief Electoral Officer’s opinion, likely be confused with it;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the party has at least three officers in addition to its leader and has appointed a chief agent and an auditor; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Chief Electoral Officer is satisfied that the party has provided the information required under subsection 385(2) and that the information is accurate.

Section.Text: In the period of 30 days after the deregistration of a political party,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: no application for another political party to become a registered party shall be accepted — and no report under section 405 is effective — if the application or report would permit another political party to use a name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo that would, in the Chief Electoral Officer’s opinion, likely be confused with that of the deregistered party; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a new application is made for the registration of the deregistered party under the name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo that it had at the time of its deregistration, the Chief Electoral Officer shall not refuse the application on the ground that it does not comply with subparagraph 387(a)(i).

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall, as soon as feasible after the day on which the application is received, inform the leader of a political party who has applied for the party to become registered whether or not the party is eligible for registration under section 387. If the party is not eligible, the Chief Electoral Officer shall also indicate which of that section’s requirements have not been met.
A political party whose leader has been informed under subsection (1) that it is eligible loses its eligibility if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it contravenes any of section 391, subsection 395(1), sections 399 to 402, subsections 405(1), (3) and (4) and 406(1) and section 407;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one of its officers is not eligible under subsection 395(2) and the party has not complied with subsections 395(3) and (4);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its chief agent is not eligible under section 397 and the party has not complied with section 400; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: its auditor is not eligible under section 398 and the party has not complied with section 400.

Subsection.Text: An eligible party becomes a registered party if it has at least one candidate whose nomination has been confirmed for an election and its application to become registered was made at least 60 days before the issue of the writ or writs and has not been withdrawn.

An eligible party whose application was made after the 60 days referred to in subsection (1) becomes a registered party for the next general election — or any by-election that precedes it — if it satisfies the requirements of that subsection for that election.
The Chief Electoral Officer shall, as soon as feasible after the end of the 48-hour period following the close of nominations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inform the leader of an eligible party that meets the requirements of subsection (1) that the party has been registered; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a general election, inform the leader of an eligible party that does not meet the requirements of subsection (1) that the party has not been registered.

Subsection.Text: An eligible party, other than one referred to in subsection (2), loses its eligibility on being informed under paragraph (3)(b) that it has not been registered.

For the purposes of sections 363, 367, 376, 430, 437 and 444, an eligible party that becomes a registered party under subsection (1) is deemed to have been registered from the day of the issue of the writ or writs.

For the purposes of section 429.1 and — despite subsection (5) — sections 363 and 367, an eligible party that becomes a registered party under subsection (1) is deemed to have been registered from the first day of the pre-election period — if any — before the election period of the election referred to in that subsection.

Section.MarginalNote: Report on agents of eligible parties
Section.Text: An eligible party shall, within 30 days after being informed under subsection 389(1) that it is eligible, provide the Chief Electoral Officer with a written report, certified by its leader or chief agent, containing the name and address of any person appointed as its registered agent and any terms and conditions to which the appointment is subject. The Chief Electoral Officer shall, on the registration of the eligible party, register that information in the registry of political parties.
Within six months after becoming a registered party, the registered party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement, prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, of its assets and liabilities, including any surplus or deficit, as of the day before the effective date of the registration;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a report on that statement made by the registered party’s auditor to its chief agent that contains the auditor’s opinion as to whether that statement presents fairly and in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles the information on which it is based; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a declaration in the prescribed form by the registered party’s chief agent that the statement is complete and accurate.

Subsection.Text: The fiscal period of a registered party is the calendar year.

Without delay after becoming registered, a political party shall, if necessary, adjust its fiscal period so that it ends at the end of the calendar year. The adjusted fiscal period shall not be less than six months or more than 18 months.

Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall maintain a registry of political parties that contains the information referred to in paragraphs 385(2)(a) to (h), (k) and (l) and subsections 396(2) and 418(2).

Heading.TitleText: Officers, Registered Agents, Auditors and Members

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), a registered party and an eligible party shall have at least three officers in addition to the leader of the party.
Only a person who is an elector and whose ordinary residence is in Canada is eligible to be an officer of a registered party or an eligible party.

In the event of the death, incapacity, resignation or ineligibility of an officer of a registered party or eligible party, or the revocation of the appointment of one, the party shall, if the remaining number of officers is less than four, appoint a replacement within 30 days.

Within 30 days after the day on which the replacement is appointed, the registered party or eligible party shall inform the Chief Electoral Officer of the appointment by providing a report under subsection 405(1).
A registered party may appoint persons to act as its registered agents, subject to any terms and conditions that the appointment specifies.

Within 30 days after the day on which a registered agent is appointed, the registered party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with a written report, certified by its leader or chief agent, that includes the registered agent’s name and address and any terms and conditions to which the appointment is subject. The Chief Electoral Officer shall register that information in the registry of political parties.
A corporation incorporated under the laws of Canada or a province is eligible to be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a chief agent or a registered agent of a registered party; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a chief agent or an agent of an eligible party.

Subsection.Text: The following persons are ineligible to be a chief agent, a registered agent or an agent:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an election officer or a member of the staff of a returning officer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a candidate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an auditor appointed as required by this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (1), a person who is not an elector;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an undischarged bankrupt; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a person who does not have full capacity to enter into contracts in the province in which the person ordinarily resides.

Subsection.Text: Only the following are eligible to be an auditor for a registered party or an eligible party:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is a member in good standing of a corporation, association or institute of professional accountants; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a partnership of which every partner is a member in good standing of a corporation, association or institute of professional accountants.

Subsection.Text: The following persons are ineligible to be an auditor:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an election officer or a member of the staff of a returning officer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a candidate or their official agent;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an officer of a registered party or an eligible party;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a chief agent of a registered party or an eligible party;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a registered agent of a registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an electoral district agent of a registered association;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a nomination contestant or their financial agent;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a leadership contestant or their leadership campaign agent; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a financial agent of a registered third party.

Section.Text: A registered party and an eligible party shall obtain from its officers, chief agent and auditor, on appointment, their signed consent to act in that capacity.

Section.MarginalNote: Replacement of chief agent or auditor

Subsection.Text: In the event of the death, incapacity, resignation or ineligibility of its chief agent or auditor, or the revocation of the appointment of one, a registered party or eligible party shall without delay appoint a replacement.

Within 30 days after the day on which the replacement is appointed, the registered party or eligible party shall inform the Chief Electoral Officer of the appointment by providing a report under subsection 405(1).

Section.MarginalNote: Only one chief agent and auditor
Section.Text: A registered party or eligible party shall have no more than one chief agent and one auditor at a time.
A registered party and an eligible party shall have at least 250 members who are electors.

Subsection.Text: No person who is ineligible to be an officer of a registered party or an eligible party shall act in that capacity.
No person who is ineligible to be a chief agent or registered agent of a registered party or an eligible party shall act in that capacity.
No person who is ineligible to be an auditor of a registered party or an eligible party shall act in that capacity.
Subject to subsection (2), no person shall act or continue to act as an officer of a registered party or an eligible party if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they know that the party does not have as one of its fundamental purposes participating in public affairs by endorsing one or more of its members as candidates and supporting their election; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the party has not made an application for deregistration under section 414.

Subsection.Text: A person referred to in subsection (1) may sign an application for deregistration under section 414.

Within 30 days after the day on which there is a change in the information in respect of a registered party or an eligible party in the registry of political parties, the party shall report the change to the Chief Electoral Officer in writing. The report shall be certified by the leader of the party.

The report of a change in the information referred to in paragraphs 385(2)(a) to (c) shall include a copy of the resolution of the party to make the change. If the changed information complies with subparagraph 387(a)(i) or (ii), the change is deemed to be effective as of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day after polling day, in the case of a report made during an election period; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the report was made, in any other case.

Subsection.Text: The report of a change of leader for a party shall include a copy of the resolution of the party to appoint the new leader, certified by the new leader and another officer of the party.

Subsection.MarginalNote: New officer, chief agent or auditor
Subsection.Text: If the report involves the replacement of an officer, the chief agent or the auditor, it shall include a copy of the signed consent referred to in section 399.
The Chief Electoral Officer shall enter any change in the information referred to in this section in the registry of political parties.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Entry in registry of electoral district associations
Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall enter any change in the information referred to in subsection (2) in the registry of electoral district associations.

Section.MarginalNote: Publication of changes to policy for the protection of personal information
Section.Text: As soon as feasible after reporting a change in its policy for the protection of personal information to the Chief Electoral Officer in writing under subsection 405(1), a registered party or an eligible party shall publish on its Internet site the updated version of the policy, incorporating the change set out in the report.

Section.MarginalNote: Confirmation of information at general election

Subsection.Text: A registered party and an eligible party shall, not later than 10 days after the issue of the writs for a general election, provide the Chief Electoral Officer with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement certified by its leader confirming the validity of the information concerning the party in the registry of political parties; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a change in that information, the report of the change made under subsection 405(1).

Subsection.Text: A registered party and an eligible party shall include with the statement or report referred to in subsection (1) a statement certified by its chief agent that sets out the names of the person or persons who are authorized by the party to endorse prospective candidates at a general election.
On or before June 30 of every year, a registered party and an eligible party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement certified by its leader confirming the validity of the information concerning the party in the registry of political parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a change in that information, the report of the change made under subsection 405(1).

Subsection.Text: On or before June 30 of every third year, beginning in 2016, a registered party and an eligible party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the names and addresses of 250 electors and their declarations in the prescribed form that they are members of the party.

On or before June 30 of every year, a registered party and an eligible party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with a declaration in the prescribed form by the leader that, having considered all of the factors relevant to determining the party’s purposes — including those described in subsection 521.1(5) — one of the party’s fundamental purposes is as described in paragraph 385(2)(j).
No leader of a political party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with information under section 385 that the leader knows is false or misleading.
No registered party and no eligible party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with information under any of sections 405 to 407 that it knows is false or misleading.
No leader of a registered party or of an eligible party shall certify, under any of sections 405 to 407, a report or statement that they know contains false or misleading information.
No leader of a political party shall make a declaration referred to in section 385, 405 or 407 that they know is false or misleading.
No person shall make a declaration referred to in paragraph 385(2)(i) or subsection 407(2) that they know is false or misleading.

Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall, effective on the expiry in a general election of the period for the confirmation of nominations under subsection 71(1), deregister a registered party that, at that time, has not endorsed a candidate in that general election.

Subsection.Text: If the Chief Electoral Officer is not satisfied that a registered party is in compliance with subsection 395(1) or section 402, he or she shall, in writing, notify the party that it is required to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: show its compliance with subsection 395(1) within 60 days after the day on which the party receives the notice; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: show its compliance with section 402 within 90 days after the day on which the party receives the notice.

Subsection.Text: If the Chief Electoral Officer is satisfied that the party has made reasonable efforts to comply with subsection 395(1) or section 402 within the time set out in the notice, he or she may, in writing, notify the party that it has another period of up to 60 or 90 days, as the case may be, in which to comply.
The Chief Electoral Officer shall deregister a registered party if it fails to comply with a notice under subsection (1) or (2), as the case may be.

Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall give notice of a deregistration under section 409 or 410 to the registered party and its chief agent and of the resulting deregistration under section 417 to the registered associations and their financial agents.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may deregister a registered party if the party fails to provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any of the documents referred to in section 392;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a report under subsection 396(2) concerning the appointment of a registered agent;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any of the documents referred to in subsection 400(2) or 405(1) or (4) with respect to a replacement of its auditor or chief agent;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: either of the documents referred to in subsections 405(1) and (3) with respect to a change of its leader;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a report in accordance with subsection 405(2) of a change in the registered information on its name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo mentioned in paragraphs 385(2)(a) to (c);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a report under subsection 405(1) concerning a change in any other registered information;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: confirmation under subsection 406(1) or section 407 of the validity of the registered information;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a report that is required to be filed under subsection 476.1(1) by the registered party; or

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a statement that is required under subsection 478.1(1) or (2).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deregistration — failure to publish updated policy for the protection of personal information
Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may deregister a registered party if the party fails to publish an updated version of its policy for the protection of personal information on its Internet site in accordance with section 405.1.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deregistration — failure to continue to have policy for the protection of personal information
Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may deregister a registered party if the party fails to continue to have a policy for the protection of personal information referred to in paragraph 385(2)(k).

Section.MarginalNote: Deregistration — failure to file return and auditor’s report
Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may deregister a registered party if its chief agent fails

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to provide him or her with a document for a fiscal year in accordance with subsection 432(1); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to provide him or her with a document for a general election in accordance with subsection 437(1).

Section.Text: On application, other than during the election period of a general election, by a registered party to become deregistered, signed by the leader and any two officers of the party, the Chief Electoral Officer may deregister the party.

Subsection.Text: If the Chief Electoral Officer believes on reasonable grounds that a registered party, its leader, its chief agent or one of its other officers has omitted to perform any obligation referred to in section 412 or 413, the Chief Electoral Officer shall, in writing, notify the party and any of its officers who are named in the registry of political parties that the party or officer must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: rectify the omission by the discharge of that obligation,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: within 5 days after receipt of the notice, in the case of a failure to comply with subsection 406(1), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: within 30 days after receipt of the notice, in any other case; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: satisfy the Chief Electoral Officer that the omission was not the result of negligence or a lack of good faith.

Subsection.Text: If paragraph (1)(b) applies, the Chief Electoral Officer may amend the notice by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: exempting, in whole or in part, the recipients of the notice from complying with the obligations referred to in section 412 or 413; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: specifying a period for compliance with the obligations referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(i) or (ii), as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may deregister a registered party if its leader, its chief agent or one of its officers fails to comply with a notice referred to in subsection (1) or with a notice amended under subsection (2).
If the Chief Electoral Officer proposes to deregister a registered party under section 414 or subsection 415(3), he or she shall, in writing, so notify the party and its registered associations.
The notice shall specify the effective date of the deregistration, which shall be at least 15 days after the day on which the notice is sent.
The notice shall be sent by registered mail or by a method of courier service that provides proof of mailing, a record while in transit and a record of delivery.

Section.MarginalNote: Effect of deregistration of registered party
Section.Text: If a registered party is deregistered, its registered associations are also deregistered.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall without delay cause a notice of the deregistration of a registered party and of its registered associations to be published in the Canada Gazette.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Entry of deregistration in registry of political parties
Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall indicate the deregistration of the party in the registry of political parties.

Section.MarginalNote: Continuation of registered status for limited purpose
Section.Text: A registered party that is deregistered continues to have the obligations of a registered party for the purpose of section 420.
The chief agent of a deregistered political party shall, within six months after the day of its deregistration, provide the Chief Electoral Officer with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the documents referred to in subsection 432(1) for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the portion of its current fiscal period ending on the day of its deregistration, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any earlier fiscal period for which those documents have not already been provided under that subsection; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the documents referred to in subsection 437(1), for any general election for which those documents have not already been provided under that subsection.

Subsection.Text: Two or more registered parties may, at any time other than during the period beginning 30 days before the issue of a writ for an election and ending on polling day, apply to the Chief Electoral Officer to become a merged registered party.
An application to merge two or more registered parties shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be certified by the leaders of the merging parties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be accompanied by a resolution from each of the merging parties approving the proposed merger; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: contain the information required from a political party to become a registered party, except for the information referred to in paragraph 385(2)(i).

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall amend the registry of political parties by replacing the names of the merging parties with the name of the merged party if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the application for the merger was not made in the period referred to in subsection 421(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: he or she is satisfied that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the merged party is eligible for registration under this Act, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the merging parties have discharged their obligations under this Act, including their obligations to report on their financial transactions and their election expenses and to maintain valid and up-to-date information concerning their registration.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall notify the officers of the merging parties in writing whether the registry of political parties is to be amended under subsection (1).

If the Chief Electoral Officer amends the registry of political parties, he or she shall cause to be published in the Canada Gazette a notice that the names of the merging parties have been replaced in the registry with the name of the merged party.
A merger of registered parties takes effect on the day on which the Chief Electoral Officer amends the registry of political parties under subsection 422(1).
On the merger of two or more registered parties,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the merged party is the successor of each merging party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the merged party becomes a registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the assets of each merging party are transferred to the merged party;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the merged party is responsible for the liabilities of each merging party;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the merged party is responsible for the obligations of each merging party to report on its financial transactions and election expenses for any period before the merger took effect;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the merged party replaces a merging party in any proceedings, whether civil, penal or administrative, by or against the merging party; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any decision of a judicial or quasi-judicial nature involving a merging party may be enforced by or against the merged party.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Effect of merger on registered associations
Subsection.Text: On the merger of registered parties, any registered association of a merging party is deregistered and, despite paragraph 447(c), may transfer goods or funds to the merged party or a registered association of the merged party in the six months immediately after the merger. Any such transfer is not a contribution for the purposes of this Act.

Section.Text: Within six months after a merger

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: each of the merging parties shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the documents referred to in subsection 432(1) for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the portion of its current fiscal period that ends on the day before the day on which the merger takes effect, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any earlier fiscal period for which those documents have not been provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the merged party shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement, prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, of its assets and liabilities, including any surplus or deficit, at the date of the merger,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a report on that statement made by the merged party’s auditor to its chief agent that contains the auditor’s opinion as to whether that statement presents fairly and in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles the information on which it was based, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a declaration in the prescribed form by the chief agent of the merged party that the statement is complete and accurate.

Section.Text: The chief agent of a registered party is responsible for administering its financial transactions and for reporting on them in accordance with this Act.

Subsection.Text: No person or entity, other than a registered agent of a registered party or a person authorized under subsection 381(1), shall pay the registered party’s expenses.
Subject to section 348.02, no person or entity, other than a registered agent of a registered party, shall incur the registered party’s expenses.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Expenses incurred by registered agent other than chief agent
Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (2), a registered agent — other than the chief agent — of a registered party shall, before incurring the party’s expenses, obtain the written authorization of the chief agent to incur those expenses, and shall incur them only in accordance with that authorization.
No person or entity, other than a registered agent of a registered party, shall accept contributions to the registered party or borrow money on its behalf.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Prohibition — accepting or providing goods, services or funds
Subsection.Text: No person or entity, other than a registered agent of a registered party, shall, on behalf of the registered party,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: accept a provision of goods or services, or a transfer of funds, if the provision or transfer is permitted under section 364; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide goods or services, or transfer funds, if the provision or transfer is permitted under that section.

Section.Text: A person who has a claim to be paid for a debt of a registered party shall send the invoice or other document evidencing the claim to the registered party or one of its registered agents.
If a claim for an expense is evidenced by an invoice or other document that has been sent under section 427, the claim shall be paid within three years after the day on which payment of it is due.
A person who has sent an invoice or other document evidencing a claim under section 427 may commence proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction to recover any unpaid amount

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at any time, if the registered agent refuses to pay that amount or disputes that it is payable; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after the end of the period referred to in section 428, in any other case.

Subsection.Text: The maximum amount that is allowed for partisan advertising expenses of a registered party for a pre-election period is $1,400,000.
The amount referred to in subsection (1) shall be multiplied by the inflation adjustment factor referred to in section 384 that is in effect on the first day of the pre-election period.

Section.MarginalNote: Prohibition — partisan advertising expenses more than maximum amount

Subsection.Text: No chief agent of a registered party shall incur partisan advertising expenses on the party’s behalf of a total amount of more than the maximum amount calculated under section 429.1.

No registered party shall circumvent, or attempt to circumvent, that maximum amount in any manner, including by acting in collusion with a potential candidate for the purpose of his or her engaging in partisan advertising so that the combined total of the following exceeds the maximum amount:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the potential candidate’s partisan advertising expenses that relate to the partisan advertising engaged in in collusion with the party; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the party’s partisan advertising expenses.

Subsection.Text: No third party, within the meaning of paragraph (a.1) of the definition third party in section 349, shall act in collusion with a registered party for the purpose of the registered party’s circumventing that maximum amount.

Section.Text: A registered party, or a person acting on its behalf, that causes partisan advertising to be conducted shall mention in or on the partisan advertising message that its transmission was authorized by one of the party’s registered agents.

Subsection.Text: The maximum amount that is allowed for election expenses of a registered party for an election is the product of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: $0.735 multiplied by the number of names on the preliminary lists of electors for electoral districts in which the registered party has endorsed a candidate or by the number of names on the revised lists of electors for those electoral districts, whichever is greater, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the inflation adjustment factor published by the Chief Electoral Officer under section 384 that is in effect on the date of the issue of the writ or writs for the election.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Maximum expenses: postponement of polling day
Subsection.Text: If the Governor in Council orders the postponement of an election under subsection 59(4) for one or more electoral districts, along with the corresponding extension of the election period, then the maximum amount calculated under subsection (1) for a registered party that has endorsed a candidate in that or any of those electoral districts is increased by adding to it the product of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: $0.735 multiplied by the number of names on the preliminary list of electors in the electoral districts governed by the order in which the party has endorsed a candidate, or the number of names on the revised list of electors in those electoral districts, whichever is greater, and divided by the number of days in the election period before it was extended;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the inflation adjustment factor published by the Chief Electoral Officer under section 384 that is in effect on the date of the issue of the writ or writs for the election; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of days by which the election period is extended.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Amounts not included in election expenses
Subsection.Text: For the purpose of subsections (1) and (2), an election expense of a registered party does not include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a transfer made by or on behalf of it to candidates in the election; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an expense incurred by it through a registered agent, or person authorized under subsection 381(1), who was not acting within the scope of the registered agent’s authority.

Section.MarginalNote: Prohibition — election expenses more than maximum

Subsection.Text: No chief agent of a registered party shall incur election expenses on the party’s behalf of a total amount of more than the maximum amount calculated under section 430.

No registered party and no third party, within the meaning of paragraph (b) of the definition third party in section 349, shall act in collusion with each other for the purpose of the registered party’s circumventing the maximum amount referred to in subsection (1).
For each fiscal period of a registered party, its chief agent shall provide the Chief Electoral Officer with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a financial transactions return, in the prescribed form, on the registered party’s financial transactions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the auditor’s report on the return made under subsection 435(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a declaration in the prescribed form by the chief agent that the return is complete and accurate.

Subsection.Text: A financial transactions return shall set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the total amount of contributions received by the registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of contributors;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of each contributor who made contributions of a total amount of more than $200 to the registered party, that total amount, as well as the amount of each of those contributions and the date on which the party received it;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of each contributor who has made a contribution to the registered party that includes a directed contribution as defined in subsection 365(2), the amount of the contribution, the amount of the directed contribution and the date on which the party received it;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the registered party’s assets and liabilities and any surplus or deficit in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, including a statement of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: claims that are the subject of proceedings under section 429, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: unpaid claims, including those resulting from loans made to the registered party under section 373;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the registered party’s revenues and expenses in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a statement, for each electoral district, of the commercial value of goods or services provided and of funds transferred by the registered party to a candidate or the electoral district association;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of each amount transferred to a leadership contestant out of a directed contribution as defined in subsection 365(2), the information referred to in paragraph (d) with respect to the contributor and the name of the leadership contestant to whom the amount has been transferred;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the commercial value of goods or services provided and of funds transferred to the registered party from any of its registered associations, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a return for election expenses incurred for each by-election during the fiscal period that sets out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: as an election expense, each of

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the expenses incurred by the registered party — other than accessibility expenses — whether paid or unpaid, including a statement of expenses incurred for voter contact calling services as defined in section 348.01, provided by a calling service provider as defined in that section, that indicates the name of that provider and the amount of those expenses, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the non-monetary contributions used by the registered party as an election expense, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the accessibility expenses incurred by the registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the terms and conditions of each loan made to the registered party under section 373, including the amount of the loan, the interest rate, the lender’s name and address, the dates and amounts of repayments of principal and payments of interest and, if there is a guarantor, the guarantor’s name and address and the amount guaranteed; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of contributions received by the registered party but returned in whole or in part to the contributors or otherwise dealt with in accordance with this Act.
